description.narrative: AECF-Renewable Energy and Climate Change Adaptation (REACT) is a challenge fund that aims to co-finance and stimulate, innovative private investments in renewable energy and climate adaptation in Tanzania. It is implemented by AGRA (Alliance for Green Revloution in Africa).

Det tredje rundan av AECF REACT kommer att utlysas som en tävling där företag ansöker om finansiering för innovativa affärsidéer inom förnybar energi. Syftet är att öka tillgången till förnybar energi till låg kostnad samt anpassning till klimatförändringar på den tanzaniska landsbygden genom ökade affärsinvesteringar och nya affärsmodeller.
Det övergripande syftet med insatsen är att bidra till minskad fattigdom i Tanzania genom förbättrad tillgång till energi och minskad sårbarhet i förhållande till klimatförändringar. Insatsen ska främja företags investeringar och innovationer inom billig förnybar energi och klimatanpassningsteknologi genom att erbjuda lån och bidrag som företagen måste matcha med minst motsvarande summa. Ansökningar måste visa tydlig fattigdomsinriktning tex genom att bidra till ökade inkomster, jobbskapande och produktivitet eller minsakde kostander för fattiga människor.

description.narrative: This conclusion on performance report covers the period of July 2019 to 30 June 2020 and provides a summary of the performance against the work plan of AECF Renewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies (REACT) for Round 1 & Round 2 and Round 3 (R1, R2 & R3), Impact, key challenges and lessons learned. Overall REACT R1-3 has been contuing giving good results, despite of suspending the fund utilization and disbursment for the financial year 2019, this is based on the output achieved. REACT projects face a challenging business environment. Innovation has been hampered in recent years by high policy and regulatory uncertainty and significant barriers to importing climate resilient technology. Despite this, huge energy demand, rapid technological progress and development partner support has resulted in success for many REACT start-ups and the programme is generating impressive results ondevelopment benefits. Over 80% of the whole REACT portfolio consists of start-up companies, reflecting the still nascent sector addressing climate change. The portfolio is dominated by companies with renewable energy business models which account for 56%. Of these, the cluster of companies dealing in solar and micro solar photovoltaic (PV) systems (Home Solar Systems) continue to show tremendous growth and have contributed the highest development and environmental impact, accounting for over 76% of renewable energy beneficiaries in 2019/20. Adaption business models make up the remaining 31% of the portfolio. REACT R1-3 projects are located across country in Tanzania. In July 2019 - June 2020, the REACT R3 Legacy Programme recorded an overall development impact of 147,405 households (737, 025 people) benefiting (either as consumers of their products and services or as suppliers to the companies), with an average net annual benefit of US$41 per household. The total net development impact was US$7.3 million in 2019/20 (cumulative of US$ 46.5 million since 2015), a figure which not only considers the benefit delivered to households, but also includes the effect of 550 direct jobs supported and the resulting wage bill. For REACT, additional revenues to SMEs (micro-enterprises or rural entrepreneurs) also form part of the development impact, and if this is considered, then the total net development impact rises to US$ 8.86 million (cumulative of US$ 54.3 million since 2015). In terms of its environmental impact, 1.97 MW of clean electricity capacity has been installed by REACT R3 energy projects to date. 23,570t of CO2 emission reductions were recorded during 2019/20 with a cumulative 71,361 million tonnes since REACT R3 began.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
